chunks.content: Options Alpha's core philosophy: Trade probabilities, not predictions. Key principles: (1) Sell premium to have time (theta) working for you. (2) Use probability of profit (POP) as primary metric, not P/L potential. (3) Small, consistent wins compound better than home runs. (4) Win rate matters more than win size when selling premium. Research basis: Over 10+ years of backtesting shows selling options with POP > 70% and managing at 50% profit generates consistent returns. The math: If you win 80% of trades at $50 profit and lose 20% at $150 loss, expected value = (0.80 * $50) - (0.20 * $150) = $40 - $30 = +$10 per trade. Volume and consistency beat magnitude.

Options Alpha portfolio allocation framework: (1) CORE (60-70%): High-probability, defined-risk trades like iron condors and credit spreads on broad ETFs (SPY, IWM, QQQ). Low maintenance, consistent returns. (2) EXPLORE (20-30%): Individual stock plays, earnings trades, higher-risk strategies. Where you test new ideas. (3) INCOME (10-20%): Covered calls and cash-secured puts on stocks you own/want to own. True passive income layer. Rebalancing: Review allocation monthly. Move winning EXPLORE strategies to CORE. Cut losing EXPLORE strategies. Goal: Build a self-sustaining options portfolio generating 1-3% monthly returns.

A short strangle sells both an OTM put and OTM call on the same underlying. Construction: Sell 1 OTM put (delta ~0.16). Sell 1 OTM call (delta ~0.16). Same expiration, typically 45 DTE. Profit zone: Between the two strikes minus premium. Max profit: Total credit received. Max loss: Unlimited (undefined risk strategy). Breakevens: Put strike - total credit, Call strike + total credit. Best conditions: IV Rank > 50%, range-bound expectation, liquid underlying. Management: Close at 50% profit or 21 DTE. If tested, roll untested side closer to collect more credit. Risk: Requires margin and risk tolerance for undefined risk. Position size smaller than spreads.

A long straddle buys both an ATM call and ATM put, betting on a large move in either direction. Construction: Buy 1 ATM call. Buy 1 ATM put. Same strike (at or near current price), same expiration. Cost: Premium paid for both options (expensive). Profit: Unlimited in either direction if move exceeds total premium paid. Max loss: Total premium paid (if underlying stays at strike). Best conditions: IV Rank < 30% (options cheap), expected catalyst (earnings, FDA, etc.), expecting move larger than implied. Breakevens: Strike +/- total premium paid. Challenge: Must overcome time decay AND IV crush after event. Low probability of profit but asymmetric payoff. Use sparingly for high-conviction event plays.

A calendar spread (horizontal spread) profits from time decay differential. Construction: Sell 1 near-term option. Buy 1 longer-term option. Same strike, different expirations. Example: Sell 30-DTE $50 call, Buy 60-DTE $50 call (same strike). How it works: Near-term option decays faster (higher theta). Long-term option retains value. Net position is long theta and long vega. Ideal conditions: Low IV (expect IV to rise), expecting underlying to stay near strike. Max profit: When underlying is exactly at strike at front-month expiration. Risk: Large move away from strike, IV decrease. Best for: Range-bound markets, pre-earnings IV expansion plays. Close before front-month expiration to avoid assignment risk.

A diagonal spread combines calendar and vertical spread characteristics. Construction: Sell 1 near-term OTM option. Buy 1 longer-term option (different strike). Example (Call Diagonal): Buy 60-DTE $50 call, Sell 30-DTE $55 call. Like a covered call but using a LEAPS instead of stock (poor man's covered call). Benefits: Lower capital requirement than covered calls. Defined risk. Profits from time decay of short option. Management: Roll short option monthly for ongoing income. Keep long option as 'base' position. Risks: If underlying moves significantly against long option, entire position loses. Best for: Bullish bias with income generation, capital-efficient covered call alternative. Close or roll when short option reaches 50% profit.

A butterfly spread is a limited-risk, limited-reward strategy betting on low volatility. Construction (Long Call Butterfly): Buy 1 ITM call (lower strike). Sell 2 ATM calls (middle strike). Buy 1 OTM call (higher strike). All same expiration. Profit zone: Narrow range around middle strike. Max profit: Width of wings minus debit paid. Max loss: Debit paid (very low). Best conditions: Expecting pinning action near a specific price, low volatility forecast. Use cases: Expiration plays on round numbers, earnings when expecting muted reaction. Cheap to enter, high reward-to-risk ratio but low probability of max profit. Requires precise price targeting.

Ratio spreads involve buying and selling different quantities of options. Example (Put Ratio Spread): Buy 1 ATM put. Sell 2 OTM puts. Creates a position that profits from moderate decline but has risk if underlying crashes. Front ratio spread (sell more than buy): Collects credit but has undefined downside risk. Back ratio spread (buy more than sell): Pays debit but profits from large moves. Use cases: Front ratios for income when expecting moderate moves. Back ratios for volatility plays when expecting extreme moves. Risk warning: Front ratio spreads have undefined risk - size appropriately. These are advanced strategies requiring active management.

A risk reversal expresses directional bias with minimal or zero cost. Construction (Bullish): Sell 1 OTM put. Buy 1 OTM call. Same expiration. Can be done for credit, debit, or even (zero cost). Profile: Synthetic long stock position with limited downside (to put strike). Profits if underlying rises (long call), loses if underlying falls below put strike. Use cases: Bullish conviction with capital efficiency. Hedging long stock positions. Expressing directional view without paying premium. Risk: Assigned on short put if underlying falls - must be prepared to own shares. Similar to wheel strategy entry but with upside call instead of covered call.

A jade lizard is a short put combined with a call credit spread. Construction: Sell 1 OTM put. Sell 1 OTM call. Buy 1 further OTM call. Ensure total credit > call spread width. Unique feature: If structured correctly, NO UPSIDE RISK. Max profit = Total credit (if underlying between put and short call). Downside risk = Put strike - Total credit (put assignment). Upside risk = Zero (if credit > call spread width). Best conditions: Neutral to slightly bullish bias, high IV. The 'free' upside protection makes this attractive for volatile underlyings. Trade-off: Less credit than strangle but defined upside risk. Good for earnings when upside surprise expected but want downside protection.

Assignment occurs when short option holder must fulfill obligation. For short puts: You buy 100 shares at strike price. For short calls: You sell/deliver 100 shares at strike price. Assignment triggers: ITM options at expiration (automatic). Early assignment (rare but possible, especially near ex-dividend). Handling assignment: (1) If assigned on put - now own shares, can sell covered calls (wheel). (2) If assigned on call with shares - shares sold, collect strike + original premium. (3) If assigned on naked call - must buy shares at market to deliver (dangerous). Prevention: Close positions before expiration. Roll ITM options out in time. Don't sell calls on stocks you don't own. Assignment is not failure - it's part of the strategy if you sized correctly.

Comparison of weekly (7 DTE) vs monthly (30-45 DTE) options: Weekly options: Higher theta decay rate (percentage). More gamma risk (larger delta swings). Must be more active in management. Higher frequency = more commissions. Good for quick income, event plays. Monthly options: Smoother theta decay curve. Lower gamma risk until final week. Set-and-forget friendly. Better for core portfolio positions. Options Alpha research shows: Monthly options (45 DTE) with management at 21 DTE or 50% profit outperform weeklies in risk-adjusted returns. Weeklies require more attention and have higher variance. Use weeklies for income acceleration, monthlies for core strategies.

Correlation risk: Multiple positions moving against you simultaneously. Example: Selling puts on 10 different tech stocks - they all drop together in sector sell-off. Mitigation strategies: (1) Diversify across sectors (tech, healthcare, finance, energy, etc.). (2) Diversify across asset classes (stocks, ETFs, commodities). (3) Include uncorrelated underlyings (VIX products, bonds, gold). (4) Beta-weight portfolio to SPY to see true market exposure. (5) Keep position sizes small so no single trade dominates. (6) Include some long options positions as hedges. Stress testing: Ask 'what happens if market drops 10%?' If answer is 'I lose 30%+', you have correlation risk. Target portfolio beta-weighted delta near zero for neutral stance.

Key mental models for consistent profitability: (1) BE THE CASINO: Casinos have small edge but play infinite games. You are the house when selling premium. (2) PROCESS OVER OUTCOME: A losing trade with good process is better than winning trade with bad process. (3) BASE RATES: What is the historical probability? Don't override probability with emotion. (4) POSITION SIZING > STOCK PICKING: How much you risk matters more than what you trade. (5) MEAN REVERSION: IV, prices, and volatility all revert to mean. Trade accordingly. (6) ASYMMETRIC RISK: Small consistent gains beat occasional large gains (for sellers). (7) OPPORTUNITY COST: Cash has value - don't force trades in bad setups.
